document.title: Education Alberta Program of Studies - Social Studies Kindergarten to Grade 12

DDE232D6AB08467290F0E08F231134FA.description: urban - Relating to cities or city life.

4D32CC5EB8B74D9C8EB8BB9A7A7E04ED.description:
rural - Relating to agricultural; or sparsely populated; of or relating to people who live
in the country

DD4E96B483EB4B0DA42E3232E5CD36F6.description:
physical geography -  The study of the physical characteristics of the environment, for example,
landforms, climate and bodies of water.

7912F2EB8074488AA2B2B2AFD37F0D49.description:
Inuit -  A member of any of several Aboriginal peoples who live in coastal regions of the
Canadian Arctic and in Greenland.

EF21F6F685CA4BCEBD89F016E95AEF14.description:
human geography - The branch of geography that pertains specifically to how humans adapt to their
environment.

4D7ADF0AC3E4401DBF4567A2E0A2FDF6.description: goods -  Items that are produced and have an economic value.

8538A895D43D4081B1A59D507E4084E1.description:
cultural diversity - Differences in groups having a variety of languages, ethnicity, nationalities,
within a shared space.

1D823BFDCABC483397F5749F749ED520.description:
Acadians - Descendants of approximately 100 French families who settled along the shores
of the Baie française (now the Bay of Fundy) in the area now known as New
Brunswick, Nova Scotia and Prince Edward Island.

941FB108D969484396E2BFC2E2FB8D96.description: compare information on the same topic or issue from print media, television and photographs

DD65E59D15F54A498FFBBB585A05F310.description: identify key words from gathered information on a topic or issue

64A9836E2A194A188EBB4115A6B649BB.description: use technology to support a presentation

9A5F07E2162441558222F00F7508F883.description: display data in a problem-solving context

462902D383874FFAB70C8F9552BD65C9.description: create visual images for particular audiences and purposes

791E060EF4914F969FD7859E107D95BF.description: interact with others in a socially appropriate manner

8AD6B37F907645FFBB419D4EC566E297.description: respond appropriately to comments and questions, using respectful language

949FB3DB727843E48D30756904D50C27.description: prepare and present information in their own words, using respectful language

60F66A265A774BE2BB3FDB0421ECA81E.description: demonstrate skills of oral, written and visual literacy:

B1D76530B36E4C8D8CE91E709CFD1E76.description: make predictions based on organized information

01224E43ECB9404FAAA8AFD18946BB68.description: formulate new questions as research progresses

FDEF835CC26F43478CEEDCFEDFB2E7CB.description: process information from more than one source to retell what has been discovered

1FB447B407A94B67B4723FFEC5EC4046.description: organize information from more than one source

D149A11BC4B346EB8CB0E4C2EDFC7383.description: navigate within a document, compact disc or other software program that contains links

BD223B76A6284094871A53086BBBD405.description: access and retrieve appropriate information from electronic sources for a specific inquiry

D99A852A1462462BB383498D14C08FC9.description: follow a plan to complete an inquiry

537DC49DCD224DB084C834D9060AE636.description: develop questions that reflect a personal information need

1318671031934DD1A17D5044469AA2EA.description:
participate in activities that enhance their sense of belonging within their school and
community

951B49FA5C284D6BB21E3525BF50CAB2.description:
develop age-appropriate behaviour for social involvement as responsible citizens
contributing to their community, such as:

7A9034576BB441E5AD89C85F758E900F.description: share information collected from electronic sources to add to a group task

2C13823165A24032BF2DC6A5A059F153.description: consider the needs and ideas of others

01345C5B3FD34B38AE7967D903D70F50.description: work and play in harmony with others to create a safe and caring environment

1362F002A65B4A33A85E446C02E16041.description: demonstrate the ability to deal constructively with diversity and disagreement

1F1FDA55EC67484DBF7B07DDF9427AF9.description: demonstrate skills of cooperation, conflict resolution and consensus building:

596819738FF243838AD206D0B0AE0C37.description: SOCIAL PARTICIPATION AS A DEMOCRATIC PRACTICE

0BE1A2DF572F4205A707AC07AE9053A2.description: propose new ideas and strategies to contribute to decision making and problem solving

8D7BFE63AE3B401CA6060D44A3F1F562.description: apply ideas and strategies to decision making and problem solving

19360B0F352B4FB08CB034F8717ACB28.description: demonstrate skills of decision making and problem solving:

1FEC29B6031A4CE5827AF990A468B7B5.description: use cardinal directions to locate communities studied in relation to one’s own community

D3C5B6D31EC44C0AA9A6B69E8C1B4CFE.description: apply the concept of relative location to determine locations of people and places

A59F3342C1064560A1D70ABAABFD118B.description: determine distance on a map, using relative terms such as near/far, here/there

9B34EA943EF344408B8BBCF25151D320.description: use a simple map to locate communities studied in Canada

C343875AB95749E293AC47568A5BB8E4.description: arrange events, facts and/or ideas in sequence

70D203CD0015412492079D1346C8A154.description: correctly apply terms related to time (i.e., long ago, before, after)

9EA5EED6A7FB4774AEAB6D709CC7278B.description:
compare and contrast information from similar types of electronic sources, such as
information collected on the Internet

122AB510E355457DBF12FB4C88C5749E.description: choose and justify a course of action

CBDEF52DB05C4C20A496DB834F72D1E1.description: distinguish between a fictional and a factual account about Canadian communities

1A720A387E9D475E93027C9B797137EE.description: develop skills of critical thinking and creative thinking:

8E062D6507414C36B5583C605838C4B3.description:
SKILLS AND PROCESSES FOR GRADE 2
Alberta Learning’s Information and Communication Technology (ICT) curriculum is infused throughout
the social studies program of studies. Selected ICT outcomes are suggested throughout the program and
are indicated by this symbol ->

FB09F26FFE3C4CA5A3BDD94BD3EFF6A8.description:
How is the presence of Aboriginal and/or Francophone origins reflected in the community
today?

A75C1AAF7528447FA99C8DC0BB0E5D8E.description: How have the people who live in the community contributed to change in the community?

BDD36D1A5372474C9E43A65F5D9339C5.description:
How has the population of their community changed over time (e.g., ethnic mix, age,
occupations)?

1A04C2576AE84E10A6A05D9B40FF9E57.description: What has caused changes in their community?

6F267ADBCFC348B2AC9E5E5017EB5960.description:
In what ways has our community changed over time (e.g., changes in transportation, land
use)?

74FDADCC10264750954AEDD5761B0AE0.description:
examine how the community being studied has changed, by exploring and reflecting upon
the following questions for inquiry:

DFFD26DEEB2B415E9414BC35F9D416BF.description: What individuals or groups contributed to the development of their community?

9E25BE329070425C905BD29EA920BCCE.description:
What were the reasons for the establishment of their community (e.g., original fur trade
fort, original inhabitants)?

64AA12DF4B6248A2BE68262EEAAD4775.description: What are the origins of their community?

8EBE5C9392314AD79E85BA90C7E5671B.description: What is unique about their community?

1A6CBDDF80B74F489172338D12BBFA03.description:
analyze how the community being studied emerged, by exploring and reflecting upon the
following questions for inquiry:

922DCC2088F34ACD98967E922141A25E.description: appreciate how cultural and linguistic exchanges connect one community to another

87031AEF73604239943D621DECC3E876.description: appreciate how connections to a community contribute to one’s identity

354ED588BCCA421C85F6876E64DD1A38.description: appreciate the importance of collaboration and living in harmony

2C9FFE96A06B4F1489ABD452D70018C1.description:
appreciate how Aboriginal and Francophone peoples have influenced the development of
the student’s community

006533FE620E4390BF81E28E77853B2F.description: appreciate how stories of the past connect individuals and communities to the present

F55B5A6C0B8C48508300ED98CFDAC37F.description:
General Outcome 2.2
A Community in the Past  - Students will demonstrate an understanding and
appreciation of how a community emerged, and of
how the various interactions and cooperation
among peoples ensure the continued growth and
vitality of their community.

4ECE1E3EB4CD4FD3B291415B94D8C651.description: What impact does industry have on the communities (i.e., agriculture, manufacturing)?

FD1C2BE718764D74BF437D48C0AA9D74.description: What kinds of goods and services are available in the communities?

99A492E9A3CB44A3B2B013F1EEFC87C6.description: What are the occupations in each of the communities?

8A922E3844EB48BBAC506933EE588D41.description:
What kinds of natural resources exist in the communities (e.g., fishing, agriculture,
mining)?

7E0FE3F7D38049A58665585934E0D871.description:
investigate the economic characteristics of communities in Canada by exploring and
reflecting upon the following questions for inquiry:

DD911FCD488A4C8F97E98E2C16D1532D.description:
How do the cultural and linguistic characteristics of the communities studied contribute to
Canada’s identity?

D13D4951A49D4F0D86491853DDF45E70.description:
How do these communities connect with one another (e.g., cultural exchanges, languages,
traditions, music)?

5F3C0B4BD580446CBA101064522DA849.description: What individuals and groups contributed to the development of the communities?

AED12EB5FA584374A1F4981BA33380BA.description: What are the linguistic roots and practices in the communities?

E62E1150B1DB484593711C3E39B0210E.description: How are the communities strengthened by their stories, traditions and events of the past?

48F992D397C1448A9AA9AFD775B00658.description:
What are the traditions and celebrations in the communities that connect the people to the
past and to each other?

8D23C656348A422583E7A061927ECA6A.description:
What are the cultural characteristics of the communities (e.g., special symbols, landmarks,
languages spoken, shared stories or traditions, monuments, schools, churches)?

1FEAFEB06CF547FF9478990B27016E37.description:
investigate the cultural and linguistic characteristics of an Inuit, an Acadian and a prairie
community in Canada by exploring and reflecting upon the following questions for
inquiry:

22AE8B190FD74B10B888B7D179D419E3.description: How does the vastness of Canada affect how we connect to other Canadian communities?

B7C68968CA4440848447122BA129980C.description:
What is daily life like for children in Inuit, Acadian and prairie communities (e.g.,
recreation, school)?

DB39CD4872384B6E97B94A2986ABA6BD.description: How does the physical geography of each community shape its identity?

AE51FEA907B94E2EBC8E842F3CE2AEE7.description:
What geographic factors determined the establishment of each community (e.g., soil, water
and climate)?

9C49BBEB05BF42E2A5437DD1EE8C5206.description: What are the main differences in climate among these communities?

BCFB95256763493FAE1C1BE614D23C29.description:
What are the major geographical regions, landforms and bodies of water in each
community?

E4B6E7D73ECC4FB9A87CC16FE9672A45.description: How are the geographic regions different from where we live?

8BFE58B0A4FB4E65ABC864A8CD309DAE.description: Where are the Inuit, Acadian and prairie communities located in Canada?

718F3ED4E8944851A3364872C71C7D4A.description:
investigate the physical geography of an Inuit, an Acadian, and a prairie community in
Canada by exploring and reflecting the following questions for inquiry:

B31B762B2A124038A240745E39CC40A2.description: demonstrate care and concern for the environment

18089B38BD254E4BA97B16ABBDFE470A.description: acknowledge, explore and respect historic sites and monuments

7888450B01E64A27885080EEAB332A8B.description: value oral history and stories as ways to learn about the land

833E1355F7594DCD8FE6CB35C2A1C10C.description: appreciate the diversity and vastness of Canada’s land and peoples

DCB631C5355745DB84033DFE8BE13C50.description: appreciate how a community’s physical geography shapes identity

68EAE5BD3FA5441A8862D2ED545FE0C9.description: appreciate the physical and human geography of the communities studied:

0BFC79DC7D9547DDBEA6AA8F9A9857EF.description:
General Outcome 2.1
Canada’s Dynamic
Communities -  Students will demonstrate an understanding and
appreciation of how geography, culture,
language, heritage, economics and resources
shape and change Canada’s communities.
